body_text.text: The SARS-CoV-2 virus has infected more than 1.8 million 7 people across 213 countries and killed more than 110 000 8 [1] . Emerging reports across countries indicate higher 9 COVID-19 mortality among men compared to women, but 10 the underlying reasons remain unclear [2] . The extent to 11 which this disparity is due to biological rather than 12 behavioral or comorbidity sex differences is unknown.

The SARS-CoV-2 receptor ACE2 and the co-receptor serine Fig. 1; Supplementary Fig. 1 ). 34 We then investigated lung single-cell data sets (two 35 human, one mouse) to determine whether lung club cells 36 also co-express ACE2 and TMPRSS2 (Supplementary Table 1 ). m the study by Ziegler et al [6] . (D) Human lung epithelial cells from the study by Reyfman et al [5] . Each data set was reclustered and annotated by cell type, with distribution shown in the uniform manifold approximation and projection. For each data set, a dot plot was generated showing the percentage of expression (marker radius) and the average expression level (color gradient) for the most differentially expressed genes in each cell type, as well as ACE2 and TMPRSS2. FIGREF0.text: Bobak Seddighzadeh a,b,c , Matthew R. Cooperberg d,e , Franklin W. Huang a,b,c, *

FIGREF1.text: protease TMPRSS2 are expressed in lung and other tissues 15 implicated in the clinical manifestations of COVID-19.16 However, less is known about the exact cell types 17 expressing ACE2 and TMPRSS2 that serve as cells of entry 18 and pathogenesis for SARS-CoV-2 [3].19 Intriguingly, TMPRSS2, one of the most dysregulated 20 genes in prostate cancer, is highly expressed in human 21 prostate epithelial cells and is androgen-responsive [4]. Giv-22 en high TMPRSS2 expression in the prostate, we investigated 23 whether TMPRSS2 and ACE2 are co-expressed in human 24 prostate epithelial cells. Using publicly available single-cell 25 RNA sequencing data, we analyzed 24 519 epithelial cells 26 from a normal human prostate data set. In this data set 27 (Supplementary material), 0.32% of all epithelial cells (78 of 28 24 519) expressed ACE2 and 18.65% expressed TMPRSS2 29 (4573 of 24 519). Overall, the prostate cell types co-30 expressing ACE2 and TMPRSS2 were hillock and club cells 31 that were originally identified in lung. We identified 0.61% 32 of club cells and 0.40% of hillock cells that were double-33 positive (

FIGREF2.text: Double-positive cells were found in 16.07% (18 of 112) of 38 human lung secretory cells in data set 1, 0.33% (7 of 2113) of 39 human lung club cells in data set 2, and 1.86% (48 of 2578) of 40 mouse lung club cells in data set 3 (Supplementary Fig. 1).To test for sex differences in the expression of these 41 genes, we compared TMPRSS2 and ACE2 expression in lung 42 epithelial cell types[5]. Overall, there was no significant43 difference in TMPRSS2 expression between males and 44 females in human lung, but higher ACE2 expression in 45 males (normalized expression level 0.02 vs 0.0065 in 46 females; p < 0.001; Supplementary Fig. 2A). Examining the 47 cell types expressing ACE2 and TMPRSS2, we found that 48 pneumocytes I/II in males compared to females had a 49 higher proportion of cells with expression (Supplementary 50 Fig. 2C). It is not clear if TMPRSS2 and ACE2 expression is 51 regulated by the same process, but their expression levels 52 are positively correlated in lung cell lines (Supplementary 53 Fig. 3). In summary, we found a small percentage of prostate 54 hillock and club cells that co-express TMPRSS2 and 55 ACE2. Whether differences in TMPRSS2 and ACE2 expres-56 sion mediate SARS-CoV-2 pathogenesis and whether 57 androgen signaling can affect COVID-19 disease remain 58 to be studied; sex differences in TMPRSS2 expression alone 59 may not drive the higher burden of SARS-CoV-2 disease 60 among men.
